bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, February 23, 1923

div1.p: Griffitts reports to Carter about anti-malarial work in Alabama. He requests Carter's advice for cleaning up a pond.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, February 23, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Griffitts
Montgomery, Ala.
519 Dexter Ave.
February 2, 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Mighty glad to get your letter. It was good
of you to what you did of Darling, for I had
wondered if I had made a correct diagnosis
in two on three days association with him
It was a real treat for me to have
been with him - and a delight, also.
I feel that his visit here must have been
somewhat disappointing to him. There was
nothing much of interest to show him at
Montgomery, and, while he went to
Mobile, I know Moler could not
have gone into our work there to
best advantage. O'Connor was with him
part of the time here, and he, too, is
an interesting talker. They both are not
strong for quinine “immunization” and
are likewise in the same attitude as
I am about “manhandled” gambusia
control.

I am sending you copy of a letter to
Barker as I am writing this hurriedly.
This dam (damn!) was closed Jan. 1921.
Last year malaria was rampant. A rather
“dry-footed” survey, or surveys, was made,
and little breeding found of last summer and
Fall.- No boat was used. But there
C1
B21
2
should have been no mistery! Most of the
body in a mass of old logs, old tree tops,
etc. Much of it down as a result of logging
operations before the pond. Much down since-
bay trees, pines, horn berry, sour-wood-. Big
pine barks, cupped up, holding larvae
and pupae as of June.

To clean this pond now would bank-
rupt the power company (Houston P. Co)
Here's what I have in mind,- please
tell me what you think.
Pond 2 miles long by 500'-1/2mi. wide

1 - Clean the bad places along shore-
cutting down and throwing out the small
stuff out in water to knee deep and
5 feet landward. This partly for to
facilitate inspection.

2 - Leading out from the crooked old channel
to the shore line on each side bre
break down or cut out open ways
to the shore- say '500-1,000' apart
and 8'-10' wide- for getting through
with boat.

3 - Suspend to trees on wires or ropes
Paris Green dust (or ashes) protected from
rain containers, that may be filled
and raised to considerable height for
dusting. In this way, it seems to me
3
we may be able to dust over flotage
that could not be reached close down.

4 - The Engineer on duty in that district
will also try out the creosating of
houses.
div1.closer: sincerely yours, THD Griffitts Answered March 11/23
